skill.name: session-handoff
skill.description: Creates comprehensive handoff documents for seamless AI agent session transfers. Triggered when: (1) user requests handoff/memory/context save, (2) context window approaches capacity, (3) major task milestone completed, (4) work session ending, (5) user says 'save state', 'create handoff', 'I need to pause', 'context is getting full', (6) resuming work with 'load handoff', 'resume from', 'continue where we left off'. Proactively suggests handoffs after substantial work (multiple file edits, complex debugging, architecture decisions). Solves long-running agent context exhaustion by enabling fresh agents to continue with zero ambiguity.
skill.summary: Creates comprehensive handoff documents for seamless AI agent session transfers, solving context exhaustion in long-running sessions.
skill.author: softaworks

security_audit.summary: Security evaluation confirms this is a safe skill. Static findings were analyzed and determined to be false positives or legitimate functionality. The skill uses subprocess for git operations with hardcoded arguments (no injection risk), has built-in secret detection for security, and operates only within the user's project directory.

medium_findings.title: Subprocess Usage for Git Commands
medium_findings.description: Scripts use subprocess.run to execute git commands. Arguments are hardcoded strings, not user input. No command injection risk exists. Usage is limited to read-only git operations (status, log, diff) and project directory file operations.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Direct code inspection confirms subprocess arguments are hardcoded string arrays like ['git', 'rev-parse', '--git-dir'] with no user input concatenation

medium_findings.title: Secret Detection Patterns Flagged as Crypto
medium_findings.description: The static scanner flagged regex patterns for detecting private keys and secrets as 'weak cryptographic algorithm'. These are intentional security patterns in validate_handoff.py that scan handoff documents for accidental secret exposure before finalization.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Pattern matching in validate_handoff.py is explicitly for detecting secrets in handoff documents before they are shared - a security feature, not a vulnerability

low_findings.title: Filesystem Access in Project Directory
low_findings.description: Scripts read and write files within .claude/handoffs/ directory. This is intentional project-scoped storage with no system-level access.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: File operations are confined to project-relative path .claude/handoffs/ with no traversal outside project bounds

content.user_title: Create handoff documents for AI sessions
content.value_statement: Long-running AI sessions often lose context when reaching token limits. This skill creates structured handoff documents that let new agents seamlessly continue work without ambiguity.
actual_capabilities: Generates structured handoff documents with project context
Captures git history, modified files, and recent commits
Validates handoffs for completeness and accidental secrets
Detects stale handoffs by comparing to current git state
Supports handoff chaining for multi-session workflows
limitations: Does not access or modify code outside the project directory
Does not execute arbitrary commands or scripts
Does not persist or transmit data externally
Requires git repository for full staleness detection

use_cases.title: Long-running feature development
use_cases.description: A developer working on a complex feature across multiple sessions creates handoffs to preserve context, decisions made, and next steps for seamless resumption.
use_cases.target_user: Developers building complex features across sessions

use_cases.title: Team handoffs
use_cases.description: Team members hand off work to each other by sharing handoff documents that capture current state, blockers, and action items.
use_cases.target_user: Development teams collaborating on shared tasks

use_cases.title: Debugging session preservation
use_cases.description: After extensive debugging sessions, create handoffs that document investigation findings, tested approaches, and remaining diagnostic steps.

prompt_templates.title: Basic handoff creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a handoff document for our current work session. Include the current state, what we have accomplished, and what the next steps should be.
prompt_templates.scenario: Standard request to save session context

prompt_templates.title: Resuming from a previous handoff
prompt_templates.prompt: Resume our work using the most recent handoff document in .claude/handoffs/. Read the handoff and start with the first item in 'Immediate Next Steps'.
prompt_templates.scenario: Continuing work from a saved session

prompt_templates.title: Proactive context preservation
prompt_templates.prompt: We have made significant progress with multiple file edits. Create a handoff document to preserve this context in case we need to continue in a new session.

prompt_templates.title: Chaining handoffs for long workflows
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new handoff that continues from our previous one. Link to the most recent handoff in the chain and document what we accomplished since then.

output_examples.input: Create a handoff for implementing user authentication
output: 1. Open the file and replace [TODO: ...] placeholders
2. Focus on 'Important Context' and 'Immediate Next Steps'

best_practices: Fill in 'Important Context' with critical information the next agent MUST know - this is the most important section
Include rationale for decisions made, not just outcomes, so the next agent understands why
Validate handoffs before finalizing to catch TODOs and prevent accidental secret exposure
Link related handoffs with --continues-from to maintain context lineage across long workflows
anti_patterns: Leaving [TODO: placeholders unfilled - next agents will lack critical context
Including actual secret values in handoffs - they may be shared or committed to version control
Skipping the validation step - incomplete handoffs waste time for resuming agents
Creating handoffs only at session end - proactive handoffs during complex work preserve more context

faq.question: Where are handoff documents stored?
faq.answer: Handoffs are stored in .claude/handoffs/ within your project directory using the naming convention YYYY-MM-DD-HHMMSS-[slug].md.

faq.question: Can I share handoffs with team members?
faq.answer: Yes. Handoffs are plain markdown files in your project. Share them like any other document. The validator checks for accidental secrets before sharing.

faq.question: What makes a good handoff?
faq.answer: Focus on the 'Important Context' section with information the next agent MUST know. Include rationale for decisions, specific file locations, and clear next steps.

faq.question: How do I resume from a handoff?
faq.answer: Run list_handoffs.py to find available handoffs, read the document completely, then follow the resume checklist. Start with item #1 in 'Immediate Next Steps'.

faq.question: What if the handoff is stale?
faq.answer: Run check_staleness.py to assess freshness. If stale, review git changes and consider creating a fresh handoff or updating the existing one.

faq.question: Are secrets detected in handoffs?
faq.answer: Yes. The validate_handoff.py script scans for API keys, passwords, tokens, private keys, and connection strings. Remove any detected secrets before sharing.
